name: Tir na nOg
sources: Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: The Land of Youth, also known as Tir na nOg (Tir Na n-og), is an Irish mythological site. It was one of the many titles used for the Otherworld, often confused or merged with Fairyland. The Tuatha Dé Danann, ancient gods, were banished from this world and transformed into Fairies. The reason behind the name is that the Otherworld's inhabitants never age, and they enjoy a blissful life full of dance, love, and fruit from the evergreen trees, completely free from mortality. Legend has it that Tir na nOg's gateway is located beneath the Lough Gur, a mystical lake in the vicinity.
